title: Venlafaxine Oral: Uses, Side Effects, Interactions, Pictures, Warnings & Dosing - WebMD
description: Find patient medical information for venlafaxine oral on WebMD including its uses, side effects and safety, interactions, pictures, warnings and user ratings.
cleaned_text: Uses [Venlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-5047-VENLAFAXINE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=4870&drugname=venlafaxine+oral) is used to treat [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/understanding-depression-basics). It may improve your mood and energy level, and may help restore your interest in daily living. Venlafaxine is known as a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It works by helping to restore the balance of certain natural substances (serotonin and norepinephrine) in the [brain](www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3). How to use Venlafaxine HCL Read the [Medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) Guide provided by your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) before you start using [venlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-5047-VENLAFAXINE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=4870&drugname=venlafaxine+oral) and each time you get a refill. If you have any questions, ask your doctor or pharmacist. Take this medication by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth) as directed by your doctor, usually 2 to 3 times daily with food. The dosage is based on your medical condition and response to treatment. To reduce your risk of side effects, your doctor may direct you to start this medication at a low dose and gradually increase your dose. Follow your doctor's instructions carefully. Take this medication regularly to get the most benefit from it. To help you remember, take it at the same times each day. Keep taking this medication even if you feel well. Do not stop taking this medication without consulting your doctor. Some conditions may become worse when this drug is suddenly stopped. Also, you may experience symptoms such as confusion, mood swings, [blurred vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/why-is-my-vision-blurry), [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), tiredness, [sleep](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-disorders-faq) changes, and brief feelings similar to electric shock. Your dose may need to be gradually decreased to reduce side effects. Report any new or worsening symptoms right away. It may take several weeks to feel the benefit of this medication. Tell your doctor if your condition lasts or gets worse. Side Effects See also Warning section. [Nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), drowsiness, [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics), sleeping](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-disorders-faq), unusual [sweating](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/hyperhidrosis2), or yawning may occur. If any of these effects last or get worse, tell your doctor promptly. Remember that this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) has been prescribed because your doctor has judged that the benefit to you is greater than the risk of side effects. Many people using this medication do not have serious side effects. This medication may raise your [blood pressure](https://www.webmd.com/hypertension-high-blood-pressure/diastolic-and-systolic-blood-pressure-know-your-numbers). Check your [blood](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood) pressure regularly and tell your doctor if the results are high. Tell your doctor right away if you have any serious side effects, including: easy bleeding/bruising, decreased interest in sex, changes in sexual ability, [muscle cramps](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/muscle-spasms-cramps-charley-horse)/ [weakness](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/tc/weakness-and-fatigue-topic-overview), shaking (tremor). Get medical help right away if you have any very serious side effects, including: [cough](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/overview) that doesn't go away, severe/pounding [headache](https://www.webmd.com/migraines-headaches/migraines-headaches-basics), stools, vomit looks like coffee grounds, [eye pain](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/eye-pain-causes-symptoms-diagnosis-treatment)/swelling/redness, widened pupils, [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics) changes (such as seeing rainbows around lights at night), [seizure](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics). This medication may increase serotonin and rarely cause a very serious condition called [serotonin syndrome](https://www.webmd.com/depression/serotonin-syndrome-causes-symptoms-treatments)/toxicity. The risk increases if you are also taking other drugs that increase serotonin, so tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) of all the drugs you take (see [Drug Interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) section). Get medical help right away if you develop some of the following symptoms: fast heartbeat, [hallucinations](https://www.webmd.com/schizophrenia/what-are-hallucinations), loss of coordination, severe dizziness, [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting)/ [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergic-reaction-causes) to this drug is rare. However, get medical help right away if you notice any symptoms of a serious [allergic reaction](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/anaphylaxis-15/slideshow-allergy-triggers), including: [rash](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/common-rashes), dizziness, [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments). This is not a complete list of possible side effects. If you notice other effects not listed above, contact your doctor or pharmacist. In the US - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to FDA at 1-800-FDA-1088 or at www.fda.gov/medwatch. In Canada - Call your doctor for medical advice about side effects. You may report side effects to Health Canada at 1-866-234-2345. Warnings [Antidepressant](https://www.webmd.com/depression/depression-medications-antidepressants) [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) are used to treat a variety of conditions, including [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/understanding-depression-basics) and other mental/ [mood disorders](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/mood-disorders). These medications can help prevent [suicidal thoughts](https://www.webmd.com/help/crisis-resources-old)/attempts and provide other important benefits. However, a small number of people (especially people younger than 25) who take [antidepressants](https://www.webmd.com/depression/depression-medications-antidepressants) for any condition may experience worsening [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/depression-assessment/zz-expire), other mental/mood symptoms, or [suicidal thoughts](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/tc/suicidal-thoughts-or-threats-topic-overview)/attempts. It is very important to talk with the doctor about the risks and benefits of [antidepressant](https://www.webmd.com/depression/antidepressants-9/slideshow-antidepressants) [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) (especially for people younger than 25), even if treatment is not for a mental/mood condition. Tell the doctor right away if you notice worsening depression/other psychiatric conditions, unusual behavior changes (including possible [suicidal thoughts](https://www.webmd.com/depression/depression-recognizing-signs-of-suicide)/attempts), or other feelings, impulsive actions, severe restlessness, very rapid speech). Be especially watchful for these symptoms when a new antidepressant is started or when the dose is changed. Precautions Before taking [venlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-5047-VENLAFAXINE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=4870&drugname=venlafaxine+oral), tell your doctor or [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) if you are allergic to it; or to [desvenlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-163933/desvenlafaxine+oral/details); or if you have any other [allergies](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts). This product may contain inactive ingredients, which can cause allergic reactions or other problems. Talk to your pharmacist for more details. Before using this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), tell your doctor or pharmacist your medical history, especially of: bleeding problems, personal or history](https://www.webmd.com/health-insurance/family-history) of [glaucoma](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/glaucoma-eyes) make you dizzy or drowsy or blur your [vision](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/vision-basics). Alcohol or [marijuana](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/marijuana-use-and-its-effects) ( [cannabis](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/marijuana-use-and-its-effects)) can make you more dizzy or drowsy. Do not drive, use machinery, or do anything that needs alertness or clear vision until you can do it safely. Avoid [alcoholic](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/understanding-alcohol-abuse-basics) beverages. Talk to your doctor if you are using marijuana (cannabis). Before having surgery, tell your doctor or [dentist](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/oral-health-care-providers) about all the products you use (including [prescription drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), nonprescription drugs, and herbal products). Older adults may be more sensitive to the side effects of this drug, especially bleeding and [dizziness](https://www.webmd.com/first-aid/understanding-dizziness-basics) when standing. Older adults may also be more likely to develop a type of salt imbalance (hyponatremia), especially if they are taking " [water pills](https://www.webmd.com/hypertension-high-blood-pressure/diuretic-treatment-high-blood-pressure)" ( [diuretics](https://www.webmd.com/hypertension-high-blood-pressure/diuretic-treatment-high-blood-pressure)). Dizziness and salt imbalance can increase the risk of falling. Children may be more sensitive to the side effects of the drug, especially loss of appetite and [weight loss](https://www.webmd.com/diet/dieter-assessment/default.htm). Monitor [weight and height](https://www.webmd.com/men/weight-loss-bmi) in children who are taking this drug. During pregnancy, this medication should be used only when clearly needed. It may harm an unborn baby. Also, babies born to mothers who have used this drug during the last [3 months of pregnancy](https://www.webmd.com/baby/first-trimester-of-pregnancy) may rarely develop withdrawal symptoms such as feeding/breathing difficulties, [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), muscle stiffness, or constant crying. If you notice any of these symptoms in your [newborn](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/ss/slideshow-baby-milestones-first-year), tell the doctor promptly. Since untreated mental/mood problems (such as [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/understanding-depression-basics), anxiety, [panic attacks](https://www.webmd.com/anxiety-panic/panic-attack-symptoms)) can be a serious condition, do not stop taking this medication unless directed by your doctor. If you are planning pregnancy, become pregnant, or think you may be pregnant, immediately discuss the benefits and risks of using this medication during pregnancy with your doctor. This drug passes into [breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts) milk and may have undesirable effects on a nursing [infant](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/ss/slideshow-baby-milestones-first-year). Consult your doctor before breast-feeding. Interactions [Drug interactions](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12) may change how your [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) work or increase your risk for serious side effects. This document does not contain all possible drug interactions. Keep a list of all the products you use (including prescription/nonprescription drugs and herbal products) and share it with your doctor and [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions). Do not start, stop, or change the dosage of any medicines without your doctor's approval. Some products that may interact with this drug are: other drugs that can cause bleeding/bruising (including antiplatelet drugs such as [clopidogrel](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-5190/clopidogrel+oral/details), [NSAIDs](https://www.webmd.com/arthritis/features/pain-relief-how-nsaids-work) [dabigatran](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-154839/pradaxa+oral/details)/ [warfarin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-3949/warfarin+oral/details)). [Aspirin](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-3-ASPIRIN+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=1082&drugname=Aspirin+Oral) can increase the risk of bleeding when used with this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx). However, if your doctor has directed you to take low-dose [aspirin](https://www.webmd.com/heart/rm-quiz-aspirin) for [heart attack](https://www.webmd.com/heart-disease/heart-disease-heart-attacks) or [stroke prevention](https://www.webmd.com/stroke/tc/stroke-cause) (usually 81-162 milligrams a day), you should continue taking it unless your doctor instructs you otherwise. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. Taking MAO inhibitors with this medication may cause a serious (possibly fatal) [drug interaction](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/video/vd-0801-atsp-12). Avoid taking treatment with this medication. Most MAO inhibitors should also not be taken for two weeks before and at least 7 days after treatment with this medication. Ask your doctor when to start or stop taking this medication. The risk of [serotonin syndrome](https://www.webmd.com/depression/serotonin-syndrome-causes-symptoms-treatments)/toxicity increases if you are also taking other drugs that increase serotonin. Examples include street drugs such as MDMA/"ecstasy," St. John's wort, certain [antidepressants](https://www.webmd.com/depression/depression-medications-antidepressants) (including SSRIs such as [fluoxetine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1774/fluoxetine+oral/details)/paroxetine, other SNRIs such as [duloxetine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-91490/duloxetine+oral/details)/milnacipran), tryptophan, among others. The risk of serotonin syndrome/toxicity may be more likely when you start or increase the dose of these drugs. Tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking other products that cause drowsiness such as [opioid](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/narcotic-pain-medications) pain or muscle (such as [cetirizine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-12065/cetirizine+oral/details), [diphenhydramine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-1428/diphenhydramine+oral/details)). Check the labels on all your medicines (such as [allergy](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/allergy-relief-10/slideshow-allergy-myths-facts) or [cough](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/cough-relief-12/slideshow-cough-treatments)-and-cold products) because they may contain ingredients that cause drowsiness. Ask your pharmacist about using those products safely. [Venlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/mono-5047-VENLAFAXINE+-+ORAL.aspx?drugid=4870&drugname=venlafaxine+oral) is very similar to [desvenlafaxine](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/2/drug-163933/desvenlafaxine+oral/details). Do not take medications containing desvenlafaxine while using venlafaxine. This medication may interfere with certain lab tests (including urine tests for [amphetamines](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/ss/slideshow-commonly-abused-drugs)), possibly causing false test results. Make sure lab personnel and all your doctors know you use this drug. Overdose If someone has overdosed and has serious symptoms such as passing out or [trouble breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/breathing-problems-causes-tests-treatments), call 911. Otherwise, call a poison control center right away. US residents can call their local poison control center at 1-800-222-1222. Canada residents can call a provincial poison control center. Symptoms of [overdose](https://www.webmd.com/mental-health/addiction/drug-overdose) may include: severe drowsiness, [seizures](https://www.webmd.com/epilepsy/understanding-seizures-basics), fast/irregular heartbeat. Do not share this [medication](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) with others. Lab and/or medical tests (such as [blood pressure](https://www.webmd.com/hypertension-high-blood-pressure/diastolic-and-systolic-blood-pressure-know-your-numbers), cholesterol) should be done while you are taking this medication. Keep all medical and lab appointments. Consult your doctor for more details. If you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. If it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. Take your next dose at the regular time. Do not double the dose to catch up. Store at room temperature away from light and moisture. Do not store in the bathroom. Keep all [medications](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx) away from children and pets. Do not flush medications down the toilet or pour them into a drain unless instructed to do so. Properly discard this product when it is expired or no longer needed. Consult your [pharmacist](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/features/pharmacists-they-do-more-than-fill-prescriptions) or local waste disposal company.
